head.title: To Save Power, the Old-Fashioned Way

hedline.hl1: To Save Power, the Old-Fashioned Way

abstract.p: Helen Jacobson letter on July 17 article calls for end to bans on clotheslines to save energy; drawing

Re ''Utilities Trying New Approaches to Pricing Energy'' (front page, July 17):

By reviving an age-old custom, consumption of electrical power in the summer months can be reduced. It's called ''going on line.'' Forget the computer. Just get out there and hang your laundry on a clothesline.
Unfortunately, easier said than done: many communities, like mine, do not permit residents to go ''on line.'' Circular, tripod-like clotheslines occupy little space and can be closed when not in use.
Beauty and ugliness are in the eye of the beholder. A display of colorful linens and clothing flapping in the breeze is no more an eyesore than barbecue ranges covered with tarps.
To conserve limited energy supplies for air-conditioning, which is so necessary for the sick and elderly, let's go ''on line''!
